item.title: Nuclear startups are back in vogue with small reactors, and big challenges
item.dc:creator: Tim De Chant
item.description: Small modular reactor startups are betting that mass manufacturing will help them bring costs down. But are they underestimating the challenge?

item.title: Indonesia and Malaysia block Grok over non-consensual, sexualized deepfakes
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ha
item.description: Indonesian officials said Saturday that they are temporarily blocking access to xAI’s chatbot Grok.

item.title: Wing to expand drone delivery to another 150 Walmart stores
item.dc:creator: Kirsten Korosec
item.description: The partnership will grow Wing's drone delivery service to more than 270 Walmart stores by 2027.

item.title: Google announces a new protocol to facilitate commerce using AI agents
item.dc:creator: Ivan Mehta
item.description: Google said that merchants can now offer discounts to users directly in AI mode results

item.title: SpaceX gets FCC approval to launch 7,500 more Starlink satellites
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ha
item.description: The Federal Communications Commission has given SpaceX approval to launch another 7,500 of its second generation Starlink satellites.

item.title: OpenAI is reportedly asking contractors to upload real work from past jobs
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ha
item.description: An intellectual property lawyer says OpenAI is "putting itself at great risk" with this approach.

item.title: I met a lot of weird robots at CES — here are the most memorable
item.dc:creator: Lucas Ropek
item.description: If the robots don't always give a totally accurate representation of where commercial deployment is at the moment, they do give visitors a peek at where their parent companies might be headed.

item.title: Google moonshot spinout SandboxAQ claims an ex-exec is attempting ‘extortion’
item.dc:creator: Julie Bort
item.description: A former SandboxAQ executive filed a wrongful termination lawsuit filled with shocking allegations. The company is fighting back, hard.

item.title: CES 2026: Everything revealed, from Nvidia’s debuts to AMD’s new chips to Razer’s AI oddities
item.dc:creator: Morgan Little
item.description: CES 2026 is in full swing in Las Vegas, with the show floor open to the public after a packed couple of days occupied by press conferences from the likes of Nvidia, Sony, and AMD and previews from Sunday’s Unveiled event.

item.title: How the Sleepbuds maker, Ozlo, is building a platform for sleep data
item.dc:creator: Sarah Perez
item.description: Ozlo Sleepbuds are going to have a big year, with new products, AI features, and more.

item.title: Meta signs deals with three nuclear companies for 6-plus GW of power
item.dc:creator: Tim De Chant
item.description: Two smaller companies, Oklo and TerraPower, along with Vistra, a large energy company, just signed agreements with Meta.

item.title: X restricts Grok’s image generation to paying subscribers only after drawing the world’s ire
item.dc:creator: Ram Iyer
item.description: Elon Musk's AI company has restricted Grok's controversial AI image-generation feature to only paying subscribers on X, after the tool invited heated criticism from across the world for letting users generate sexualized images of women and children.

item.title: The venture firm that ate Silicon Valley just raised another $15 billion
item.dc:creator: Connie Loizos
item.description: In a blog post published Friday morning, Ben Horowitz writes that "as the American leader in Venture Capital, the fate of new technology in the United States rests partly on our shoulders." It's the kind of statement certain to cause agita at rival firms.

item.title: Anthropic adds Allianz to growing list of enterprise wins
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Szkutak
item.description: Anthropic announces its first enterprise deal of 2026, which includes building agents for, and giving Claude code to, Allianz.

item.title: Inside CES 2026’s “physical AI” takeover
item.dc:creator: Theresa Loconsolo
item.description: After years of chatbots and image generators, AI is finally leaving the screen. At CES 2026, that shift became impossible to ignore.  The annual tech showcase in Las Vegas was dominated by “physical AI” and robotics, from Boston Dynamic’s newly redesigned Atlas humanoid robot to AI-powered ice makers (yes, really). The companies in attendance clearly want consumers […]

item.title: Data security startup Cyera hits $9B valuation six months after being valued at $6B
item.dc:creator: Julie Bort
item.description: Cyera raised another $400 million just six months after its last huge round.

item.title: Governments grapple with the flood of non-consensual nudity on X
item.dc:creator: Russell Brandom
item.description: For the past two weeks, X has been flooded with AI-manipulated nude images, created by the Grok AI chatbot — and governments around the world are promising to take action.

item.title: GTMfund has rewritten the distribution playbook for the AI era
item.dc:creator: Maggie Nye, Isabelle Johannessen
item.description: Building software products has never been easier, so why are so many well-funded startups failing to take off no matter how good their product is? In this season finale episode of Build Mode, our guest has an answer: Startups have focused too much on product development and not enough on distribution excellence. Paul Irving is partner and […]

item.title: Critics pan spyware maker NSO’s transparency claims amid its push to enter US market
item.dc:creator: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
item.description: The infamous spyware maker released a new transparency report claiming to be a responsible spyware maker, without providing insight into how the company dealt with problematic customers in the past.

item.title: EverNitro is simplifying the process of crafting silky nitro coffee at CES 2026
item.dc:creator: Lauren Forristal
item.description: EverNitro is positioning itself against competitors such as NitroBrew as a long-term more affordable all-in-one solution. “We offer the quality of a commercial tap with the footprint of a coffee maker. While others sell you gas, we give you technology to harvest it for free,” founder and CEO Terry Tan said.
